_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Chester Water Authority (CWA) operates the Octoraro Water Treatment Plant in Little Britain Township, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. The treatment plant processes include use of chlorine for disinfection. Chlorine is regulated under EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations.  CWA carefully stores and handles chlorine.  CWA's Risk Management Program describes the chemical hazards and the measures taken to prevent accidental releases.   CWA's RMP has been developed and implemented in accordance with EPA RMP regulations (40 CFR 68) and guidelines specifically created for water treatment plants (WTPs).



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Chester Water Authority has the following policy addressing its commitment to accident prevention and risk management:

"The Chester Water Authority is committed to protecting its employees, the public, and the environment from accidental releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities. CWA will implement safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to minimize the risks presented by hazardous materials used at its facilities. If there is an accidental release, CWA will either provide, or request from others, immediate emergency response to minimize the effects of the release. CWA will also immediately notify the public, through county emergency management agencies, of any actions necessary to ensure public protection and safety.



Accidental Release Prevention Program Overview



CWA's Octoraro treatment plant has a release prevention program encompassing the elements of the EPA RMP Prevention Program 2 requirements.  The program delineates accountability and responsibility for each of the prevention program elements. The prevention program includes: maintaining up-to-date chemical and process Safety Information; conducting periodic Hazard Reviews, maintaining up-to-date Operating Procedures; Training employees on the procedures, hazards, and safe work practices; Ma

intenance of chlorine process equipment; conducting Audits of compliance with these rules; and completing Incident Investigations.



Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



Key chemical-specific accident prevention steps include:



> Emergency valve actuators that can be remotely activated to shut down the chemical flow if there is a leak on piping or equipment.

> Multiple leak detectors and alarms to alert operators.

> An emergency scrubber automatically activated by a leak alarm 

> Facility and storage building security and remote monitoring from the control room.

> Button activated emergency auto-dialer system.



Five-Year Accident History



The site had a small accidental release of chlorine (about 1 lb. released to the room over about 1 minute) that caused skin contact and resulted in a blister and requiring medical treatment. It didn't escape the room due to the scrubber or cause inhalation exposure due to respirator use.



Emergency Response



CWA takes every precaution to prevent an emergency from occurring, including training and equipping its employees to abate a potential release in its initial stages before it can become an emergency.  CWA relies on Lancaster County Emergency Management Agency to provide emergency response personnel and equipment.

CWA's emergency action plan includes procedures for emergency notifications, evacuation of non essential plant personnel from the affected area and coordination with emergency responders by qualified plant personnel. 



Planned Safety Improvements



The Authority works to safely manage chemical hazards present at the Octoraro Treatment Plant.  This includes maintaining equipment and facilities, updating procedures, following safe work practices and making improvements to our practices and facilities.  Periodically, we Audit our program, update our Hazard Review and implement any additional improvements recommended by these evaluations. 

    

We have already updated procedures and enhanced the function

ality of alarms based on the most recent Hazard Review and additional audible alarms will be added. 

    

Note: Limitations in CDX/RMP*eSubmit required adjusting the Alternative Release Total lbs. up to the minimum value, the release rate exiting the scrubber of 0.004 lb/min was rounded down by the system to zero, and the distance to endpoint was adjusted to the minimum value.
